subSense.def: a man
subSense.example:
A young
fellow came up to me and asked me the
time
Who's that fellow with a beard?

subSense.def:
a person who belongs to the same
group
subSense.example:
I was OK on the boat, but sev-
eral of my fellow passengers were sick

subSense.def:
a thick material made of
wool fibres pressed together

relating to
women or girls
subSense.example: a female athlete

subSense.def:
re-
lating to the sex of an animal, insect or
bird which gives birth to young or pro-
duces eggs
subSense.example: a female kitten

subSense.def:
relating
to a flower which produces seeds

like a
woman or suitable for a woman
subSense.example:
Her
long white silk dress was very feminine

subSense.def:
a type of wall made of
wood or wire, used to keep people or an-
imals in or out of a place
subSense.example:
The fence
was blown down

The boys looked
through the hole in the fence

The
builders put up a fence round the con-
struction site

subSense.def:
wild
and angry
subSense.example: a ferocious dog

subSense.def:
a boat which carries
cars and trucks or people across a
stretch of water
subSense.example:
We are going to take
the night ferry to Belgium

There's a
ferry across the Rhine here

subSense.def:
a religious
celebration which is celebrated at the
same time each year and is usually a
public holiday
subSense.example:
The tour will visit
Hong Kong for the Lantern Festival

subSense.def:
an event, often lasting several days,
where entertainment is provided
subSense.example:
We
saw some excellent plays at the Edin-
burgh Festival this year

subSense.def:
to go to a place and
bring someone or something back
subSense.example:
It's
your turn to fetch the children from
school
Can you fetch me the atlas

subSense.def:
a state in which the
body's temperature is higher than nor-
mal
subSense.example:
You must stay in bed until the fe-
ver goes down

subSense.def: not many
subSense.example: She has very few friends at work

We
go to fewer concerts than last year

subSense.def:
a lie about something unim-
portant
subSense.example:
That was a little fib,
wasn't it

subSense.def:
a small thread of
material
subSense.example:
From the fibres left at the
scene of the murder, the police could
work out what the murderer had been
wearing

subSense.def:
thin threads in foods such as
vegetables and bread, which cannot be
digested, but which helps food to pass
through your body
subSense.example:
You need to eat
more fibre

body.subSense:
novels ć fiction
writers such as Graham Greene ć To
find the latest novels you must look in
the fiction section of the library. (NOTE:
no plural)

subSense.def:
a piece of ground on
a farm, used for keeping animals or
growing crops
subSense.example: a field of potatoes
The sheep are in the field

subSense.def:
a piece of
ground for playing a game
subSense.example:
a football
field
The two teams ran onto the field

subSense.def:
very angry and
likely to attack
subSense.example:
Watch out -that dog
looks fierce

subSense.def: strongly
subSense.example:
She is
fiercely independent

subSense.def: the number 15
subSense.example:
There are fifteen players in a rugby
team
She's fifteen (years old)
Come and see me in fifteen minutes
The train leaves at nine fifteen (9.15)

subSense.def:
relating to
number 15 in a series
subSense.example:
the fifteenth of
July or July the fifteenth (July 15th)

That's the fifteenth phone call I've made
this morning

It will be her fifteenth
birthday next week

subSense.def:
number 15
in a series
subSense.example:
Our house is the fifth on the
right

subSense.def:
relating to number 5
in a series
subSense.example:
The fifth of May or May the
fifth (May 5th)

It's his fifth birthday
tomorrow

subSense.def:
one part of five equal
parts

relating to
number 50 in a series

the
number fifty in a series
subSense.example:
He's fiftieth on
the waiting list

subSense.def: the number 50
subSense.example:
My
mother made fifty pots of jam

He's
fifty (years old)

subSense.def:
an occasion on which
people try to hurt each other or knock
each other down
subSense.example:
He got into a fight
with boys who were bigger than him

Fights broke out between the demon-
strators and the police

subSense.def:
a situation in
which people do everything they can to
stop something from happening
subSense.example:
a
fight against the new developments

subSense.def:
to be involved in a situation in
which people try to hurt each other or
knock each other down
subSense.example:
Rival gangs
fought in the street

body.subSense:
2. to do everything
you can try to stop something from hap-
pening ć We are committed to fighting
crime. ć Doctors are fighting to control
the disease. (NOTE: fights -fighting -
fought /fɔ t/ -has fought)

subSense.def:
a written number,
e.g. 35
subSense.example:
I can't read the figure on the
order -is it 250?

He added up the fig-
ures on the bill

Cheques have to be
made out in both words and figures

subSense.def: the shape of a person
subSense.example: the figures at the front of the painting

We could see some figures through the
mist

subSense.def:
to consider
or think something
subSense.example:
I figure the costs
will be high

We figured that you'd be
late because of the show

Had you fig-
ured on being there before two o'clock?

subSense.def:
a metal tool used for
making rough surfaces smooth
subSense.example:
Use a
file to round off the edges of the metal

subSense.def:
a container similar to an envelope, used
for keeping documents in
subSense.example:
When you
have finished with the papers, put them
back in the file

The police have a file
on him

subSense.def:
a set of information held in a
computer
subSense.example:
Type the name of the file
and then press 'enter'

subSense.def:
to make something full; to
become full
subSense.example:
He filled the bottle with
water

She was filling the boxes with
presents
The bucket filled slowly

subSense.def:
moving pictures
shown at a cinema or on TV
subSense.example:
Have you
seen this old Laurel and Hardy film?
We've seen the film already on TV

subSense.def:
a
roll of material which you put into a
camera to take photographs or to record
moving pictures
subSense.example:
I must buy another
film before the wedding

Do you want
a colour film or a black and white one?

subSense.def: a thin layer of something
subSense.example:
A film of
grease had formed on the walls around
the oven

subSense.def:
to take pictures of
something or someone with a camera
subSense.example:
Security cameras filmed him robbing
the bank

'Star Wars' was filmed in
1977

body.subSense:
very dirty ć Your
hands are absolutely filthy! (NOTE: filth-
ier -filthiest)

subSense.def:
a thin part on the body of a
fish which sticks out and helps it to
swim
subSense.example:
From the beach they could see a
shark's fin in the sea

subSense.def:
last; coming at
the end
subSense.example:
This is your final warning -if
your work doesn't improve you will
have to go

The competition is in its fi-
nal stages

subSense.def:
the last competition
in a series between several teams or
competitors
subSense.example:
I thought they would win
a couple of rounds, but I never imagined
they would get to the final

subSense.def:
at last; in the
end
subSense.example:
The police finally cleared up the
mystery

The little boy finally turned
up in Edinburgh

subSense.def:
money, espe-
cially money which belongs to the pub-
lic or to a company
subSense.example:
How are you go-
ing to raise the finance for the project?

My finances are in a poor state at the
moment

subSense.def:
to provide money for
something
subSense.example:
How are you going to fi-
nance your course at university if you
don't have a grant?

The redevelop-
ment of the city centre is being financed
locally

subSense.def:
relating
to money
subSense.example:
What is our financial posi-
tion?

The company has got into finan-
cial difficulties

subSense.def:
to see where some-
thing hidden or lost is after looking for
it
subSense.example: I found a £2 coin behind the sofa

Did she find the book she was looking
for?

body.subSense:
2. to discover something which was
not known before ć No one has found a
cure for the common cold yet. (NOTE:
finds -finding -found /faυnd/)

subSense.def: dry and sunny
subSense.example:
We'll go for a walk to-
morrow if the weather stays fine

Let's
hope it's fine for the village fair next
week

subSense.def: well; healthy
subSense.example:
I was ill in bed
yesterday, but today I'm feeling fine

subSense.def: with no problems
subSense.example:
How are things at
home? -Fine!

subSense.def: acceptable
subSense.example:
It's fine
to wear casual clothes for this meeting

subSense.def: very thin or very small
subSense.example:
Use a sharp
pencil if you want to draw fine lines

I
can't read the notice -the print is too
fine

subSense.def: satisfactorily or well
subSense.example: It's working fine

subSense.def:
money which
you have to pay as a punishment for

subSense.example:
I had
to pay a £25 fine for parking in a No

subSense.def:
to make someone
pay money as a punishment for having
done something wrong
subSense.example:
He was fined
£25 for parking on double yellow lines

subSense.def:
one of the parts at
the end of your hand, sometimes not in-
cluding the thumb
subSense.example:
He wears a ring on
his little finger

He pressed the button
with his finger

subSense.def:
one of the parts of a
glove that cover the fingers
subSense.example:
I must
mend my glove -there's a hole in one of

Gloves without fingers are
called 'mittens'

subSense.def:
a piece of food
shaped like a finger
subSense.example:
a box of chocolate
fingers

subSense.def:
the hard
thin part covering the end of a finger

to do something
completely
subSense.example:
Haven't you finished your
homework yet?

Tell me when you've
finished reading the paper

You can't
go out until you've finished doing the
washing up

subSense.def: to come to an end
subSense.example:
The
game will finish at about four o'clock

subSense.def:
something which is
burning and gives off heat
subSense.example:
They burnt
the dead leaves on a fire in the garden

subSense.def: something which heats
subSense.example:
We have an
electric fire in the living room

subSense.def:
an
emergency in which something such as
a building burns
subSense.example:
They lost all their be-
longings in the fire

subSense.def:
shooting with
guns
subSense.example: The soldiers came under fire

subSense.def: to shoot a gun
subSense.example:
The gunmen
fired at the police car

We could hear
guns firing in the distance

subSense.def:
to tell
someone that they must leave their job
because of something wrong they have
done
subSense.example: She was fired for being late

subSense.def:
a hole in the
wall of a room where you can light a fire
for heating

a small tube
holding chemicals which will shine
brightly or explode when lit
solid or fixed
subSense.example:
Make sure that the ladder is firm before
you climb up

My back hurts -I think
I need a firmer mattress

subSense.def:
strong; like-
ly to change
subSense.example:
There is no firm evidence

believer in hard work

subSense.def:
a busi-
ness or company
subSense.example:
When he retired, the
firm presented him with a watch

The
firm I work for was taken over last year

subSense.def: in a firm way

the quality
of being strong or firm
determination
number 1 in a series
subSense.example: Our house is the first on the left
